items.text: **Ford Motor Company** is an [[LINK|lang_en|United_States|American]] [[LINK|lang_en|Multinational_corporation|multinational]] automaker headquartered in [[LINK|lang_en|Dearborn,_Michigan|Dearborn, Michigan]], a suburb of [[LINK|lang_en|Detroit|Detroit]]. It was founded by [[LINK|lang_en|Henry_Ford|Henry Ford]] and incorporated on June 16, 1903. The company sells automobiles and commercial vehicles under the [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_Ford_vehicles|Ford]] brand and most luxury cars under the [[LINK|lang_en|Lincoln_Motor_Company|Lincoln]] brand. Ford also owns Brazilian [[LINK|lang_en|Sport_utility_vehicle|SUV]] manufacturer [[LINK|lang_en|Troller|Troller]], an 8% stake in [[LINK|lang_en|Aston_Martin|Aston Martin]] of the United Kingdom, and a 49% stake in [[LINK|lang_en|Jiangling_Motors|Jiangling Motors]] of China. [[CITE|176|http://foundrymag.com/materials/chinese-automaker-adopts-sintercast-cgi]] It also has joint-ventures in China ([[LINK|lang_en|Changan_Ford|Changan Ford]]), Taiwan ([[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Lio_Ho|Ford Lio Ho]]), Thailand ([[LINK|lang_en|AutoAlliance_Thailand|AutoAlliance Thailand]]), Turkey ([[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Otosan|Ford Otosan]]), and Russia ([[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Sollers|Ford Sollers]]). The company is listed on the [[LINK|lang_en|New_York_Stock_Exchange|New York Stock Exchange]] and is controlled by the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_family_tree|Ford family]]; they have minority ownership but the majority of the voting power. [[CITE|197|https://forbes.com/sites/joannmuller/2010/12/02/ford-familys-stake-is-smaller-but-theyre-richer-and-remain-firmly-in-control]] [[CITE|126|https://wsj.com/articles/shareholders-again-back-ford-family-1463087314]]

Ford introduced methods for large-scale manufacturing of cars and large-scale management of an industrial workforce using elaborately engineered manufacturing sequences typified by moving [[LINK|lang_en|Assembly_line|assembly lines]]; by 1914, these methods were known around the world as [[LINK|lang_en|Fordism|Fordism]]. Ford's former UK subsidiaries [[LINK|lang_en|Jaguar_Cars|Jaguar]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Land_Rover|Land Rover]], acquired in 1989 and 2000 respectively, were sold to [[LINK|lang_en|Tata_Motors|Tata Motors]] in March 2008. Ford owned the Swedish automaker [[LINK|lang_en|Volvo_cars|Volvo]] from 1999 to 2010. [[CITE|236|http://ford.com/about-ford/news-announcements/press-releases/press-releases-detail/pr-ford-motor-company-completes-sale-33059]] In 2011, Ford discontinued the [[LINK|lang_en|Mercury_(automobile)|Mercury]] brand, under which it had marketed entry-level luxury cars in the United States, Canada, Mexico, and the Middle East since 1938.

Ford is the second-largest U.S.-based automaker (behind [[LINK|lang_en|General_Motors|General Motors]]) and the [[LINK|lang_en|Automotive_industry#By_manufacturer|fifth-largest]] in the world (behind [[LINK|lang_en|Toyota|Toyota]], [[LINK|lang_en|Volkswagen_Group|VW]], [[LINK|lang_en|Hyundai_Motor_Group|Hyundai-Kia]] and General Motors) based on 2015 vehicle production. At the end of 2010, Ford was the fifth largest automaker in Europe. [[CITE|253|http://acea.be/images/uploads/files/20110114_PRPC-FINAL-1012.xls]] The company went public in 1956 but the Ford family, through special Class B shares, still retain 40 percent voting rights. [[CITE|8|https://forbes.com/sites/joannmuller/2014/03/09/william-clay-fords-legacy-cemented-familys-dynasty]] [[CITE|126|https://wsj.com/articles/shareholders-again-back-ford-family-1463087314]] During [[LINK|lang_en|Financial_crisis_of_2007–08|the financial crisis]] at the beginning of the 21st century, it was close to bankruptcy, but it has since returned to profitability. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] Ford was the eleventh-ranked overall American-based company in the 2018 [[LINK|lang_en|Fortune_500|Fortune 500]] list, based on global revenues in 2017 of $156.7 billion. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] In 2008, Ford produced 5.532 million automobiles [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] and employed about 213,000 employees at around 90 plants and facilities worldwide.
History

caption.text: [[LINK|lang_en|Henry_Ford|Henry Ford]] (ca. 1919)
A 1910 [[LINK|lang_en|Model_T|Model T]], photographed in [[LINK|lang_en|Salt_Lake_City|Salt Lake City]]

items.text: 20th century

Henry Ford's first attempt at a car company under his own name was the [[LINK|lang_en|Henry_Ford_Company|Henry Ford Company]] on November 3, 1901, which became the [[LINK|lang_en|Cadillac_Motor_Company|Cadillac Motor Company]] on August 22, 1902, after Ford left with the rights to his name. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] The Ford Motor Company was launched in a converted factory in 1903 with $28,000 in cash from twelve investors, most notably [[LINK|lang_en|John_Francis_Dodge|John]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Horace_Elgin_Dodge|Horace Dodge]] (who would later found [[LINK|lang_en|Dodge_Brothers_Motor_Vehicle_Company|their own]] car company). The first president was not Ford, but local banker [[LINK|lang_en|John_S._Gray_(Michigan)|John S. Gray]], who was chosen to assuage investors' fears that Ford would leave the new company the way he had left its predecessor. During its early years, the company produced just a few cars a day at its factory on [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Mack_Avenue_Plant|Mack Avenue]] and later its [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Piquette_Avenue_Plant|factory on Piquette Avenue]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Detroit|Detroit]], [[LINK|lang_en|Michigan|Michigan]]. Groups of two or three men worked on each car, assembling it from parts made mostly by supplier companies contracting for Ford. Within a decade, the company would lead the world in the expansion and refinement of the [[LINK|lang_en|Assembly_line|assembly line]] concept, and Ford soon brought much of the part production in-house in a [[LINK|lang_en|Vertical_integration|vertical integration]] that seemed a better path for the era.
Henry Ford was 39 years old when he founded the Ford Motor Company, which would go on to become one of the world's largest and most profitable companies.
It has been in continuous family control for over 100 years and is one of the largest family-controlled companies in the world.

The first gasoline powered [[LINK|lang_en|Automobile|automobile]] had been created in 1885 by the [[LINK|lang_en|Germany|German]] inventor [[LINK|lang_en|Karl_Benz|Carl Benz]] ([[LINK|lang_en|Benz_Patent-Motorwagen|Benz Patent-Motorwagen]]). More efficient production methods were needed to make automobiles affordable for the middle class, to which Ford contributed by, for instance, introducing the first moving [[LINK|lang_en|Assembly_line|assembly line]] in 1913 at the Ford [[LINK|lang_en|Highland_Park_Ford_Plant|factory in Highland Park]].

Between 1903 and 1908, Ford produced the Models [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Model_A_(1903-04)|A]], B, C, F, K, N, R, and S. Hundreds or a few thousand of most of these were sold per year. In 1908, Ford introduced the mass-produced [[LINK|lang_en|Model_T|Model T]], which totalled millions sold over nearly 20 years. In 1927, Ford replaced the T with the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Model_A_(1927–1931)|Model A]], the first car with safety glass in the windshield. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] Ford launched the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_flathead_V8|first low-priced car with a V8]] engine in 1932.
In an attempt to compete with General Motors' mid-priced Pontiac, Oldsmobile, and Buick, Ford created the Mercury in 1939 as a higher-priced companion car to Ford.
Henry Ford purchased the Lincoln Motor Company in 1922, in order to compete with such brands as Cadillac and Packard for the luxury segment of the automobile market.

In 1929, Ford was contracted by the government of the Soviet Union to set up the [[LINK|lang_en|GAZ|Gorky Automobile Plant]] in Russia initially producing Ford Model A and AAs thereby playing an important role in the industrialisation of that country. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]

The creation of a scientific laboratory in Dearborn, Michigan in 1951, doing unfettered basic research, led to Ford's unlikely involvement in [[LINK|lang_en|Superconductivity|superconductivity]] research. In 1964, Ford Research Labs made a key breakthrough with the invention of a superconducting quantum interference device or [[LINK|lang_en|SQUID|SQUID]]. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]

Ford offered the Lifeguard safety package from 1956, which included such innovations as a standard deep-dish steering wheel, optional front, and, for the first time in a car, rear seatbelts, and an optional padded dash.

[[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] Ford introduced child-proof door locks into its products in 1957, and, in the same year, offered the first retractable hardtop on a mass-produced six-seater car.
In late 1955, Ford established the Continental division as a separate luxury car division.
This division was responsible for the manufacture and sale of the famous Continental Mark II.
At the same time, the Edsel division was created to design and market that car starting with the 1958 model year.
Due to limited sales of the Continental and the Edsel disaster, Ford merged Lincoln, Mercury, and Edsel into "M-E-L," which reverted to "Lincoln-Mercury" after Edsel's November 1959 demise.
The Ford Mustang was introduced in April 17, 1964 during New York World's Fair.
[[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] In 1965, Ford introduced the seat belt reminder light.
With the 1980s, Ford introduced several highly successful vehicles around the world.
During the 1980s, Ford began using the advertising slogan, "Have you driven a Ford, lately?" to introduce new customers to their brand and make their vehicles appear more modern.

In 1990 and 1994 respectively, Ford also acquired [[LINK|lang_en|Jaguar_Cars|Jaguar Cars]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Aston_Martin|Aston Martin]]. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] During the mid- to late 1990s, Ford continued to sell large numbers of vehicles, in a booming [[LINK|lang_en|United_States|American]] economy with a soaring stock market and low fuel prices.

With the dawn of the new century, legacy [[LINK|lang_en|Health_care_prices_in_the_United_States|health care costs]], higher fuel prices, and a faltering economy led to falling market shares, declining sales, and diminished profit margins. Most of the corporate profits came from financing consumer automobile loans through [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Motor_Credit_Company|Ford Motor Credit Company]]. [[CITE|254|http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/4297305.stm]]
21st century

By 2005, both Ford and [[LINK|lang_en|General_motors|GM]]'s corporate bonds had been downgraded to junk status, [[CITE|1|https://washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A41573-2005May6.html]] as a result of high U.S. health care costs for an [[LINK|lang_en|Aging_in_the_American_workforce|aging workforce]], soaring gasoline prices, eroding market share, and an over dependence on declining [[LINK|lang_en|Sport_utility_vehicle|SUV]] sales. Profit margins decreased on large vehicles due to increased "incentives" (in the form of rebates or low interest financing) to offset declining demand. [[CITE|37|http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4155/is_19991124/ai_n13845438]] In the latter half of 2005, Chairman Bill Ford asked newly appointed Ford Americas Division President [[LINK|lang_en|Mark_Fields_(businessman)|Mark Fields]] to develop a plan to return the company to profitability. Fields previewed the Plan, named *[[LINK|lang_en|The_Way_Forward|The Way Forward]] *, at the December 7, 2005, board meeting of the company and it was unveiled to the public on January 23, 2006. "The Way Forward" included resizing the company to match market realities, dropping some unprofitable and inefficient models, consolidating production lines, closing 14 factories and cutting 30,000 jobs. [[CITE|58|https://nytimes.com/2006/01/23/automobiles/23cnd-ford.html]]

Ford moved to introduce a range of new vehicles, including "[[LINK|lang_en|Crossover_SUV|Crossover SUVs]]" built on [[LINK|lang_en|Unibody|unibody]] car platforms, rather than more [[LINK|lang_en|Body-on-frame|body-on-frame]] chassis. In developing the hybrid electric powertrain technologies for the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Escape_Hybrid|Ford Escape Hybrid]] SUV, Ford licensed similar Toyota hybrid technologies [[CITE|80|https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C02E6DE153EF933A25750C0A9629C8B63]] to avoid patent infringements. [[CITE|102|http://businessweek.com/innovate/NussbaumOnDesign/archives/2005/11/is_ford_innovat_1.html]] Ford announced that it will team up with electricity supply company [[LINK|lang_en|Southern_California_Edison|Southern California Edison]] (SCE) to examine the future of [[LINK|lang_en|Plug-in_hybrid|plug-in hybrids]] in terms of how home and vehicle energy systems will work with the electrical grid. Under the multimillion-dollar, multi-year project, Ford will convert a demonstration fleet of [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Escape_Hybrid|Ford Escape Hybrids]] into plug-in hybrids, and SCE will evaluate how the vehicles might interact with the home and the utility's electrical grid. Some of the vehicles will be evaluated "in typical customer settings", according to Ford. [[CITE|128|http://www.eere.energy.gov/news/enn.cfm#id_11093]] [[CITE|161|https://web.archive.org/web/20071011195651/http://media.ford.com/newsroom/release_display.cfm?release=26326]]

[[LINK|lang_en|William_Clay_Ford_Jr.|William Clay Ford Jr.]], great-grandson of Henry Ford (and better known by his nickname "Bill"), was appointed executive chairman in 1998, and also became chief executive officer of the company in 2001, with the departure of [[LINK|lang_en|Jacques_Nasser|Jacques Nasser]], becoming the first member of the Ford family to head the company since the retirement of his uncle, [[LINK|lang_en|Henry_Ford_II|Henry Ford II]], in 1982. Ford sold motorsport engineering company [[LINK|lang_en|Cosworth|Cosworth]] to [[LINK|lang_en|Gerald_Forsythe|Gerald Forsythe]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Kevin_Kalkhoven|Kevin Kalkhoven]] in 2004, the start of a decrease in Ford's motorsport involvement. Upon the retirement of president and chief operations officer Jim Padilla in April 2006, Bill Ford assumed his roles as well. Five months later, in September, Ford named [[LINK|lang_en|Alan_Mulally|Alan Mulally]] as president and CEO, with Ford continuing as executive chairman. In December 2006, the company raised its borrowing capacity to about $25 billion, placing substantially all corporate assets as collateral. [[CITE|213|http://detnews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20061128%2FAUTO01%2F611280378]] Chairman Bill Ford has stated that "bankruptcy is not an option". [[CITE|235|https://forbes.com/2006/04/05/ford-bankruptcy-cuts-cx_gl_0405autofacescan15.html]] Ford and the [[LINK|lang_en|United_Auto_Workers|United Auto Workers]], representing approximately 46,000 hourly workers in North America, agreed to a historic contract settlement in November 2007 giving the company a substantial break in terms of its ongoing retiree health care costs and other economic issues. The agreement included the establishment of a company-funded, independently run [[LINK|lang_en|Voluntary_Employee_Beneficiary_Association|Voluntary Employee Beneficiary Association]] (VEBA) trust to shift the burden of retiree health care from the company's books, thereby improving its balance sheet. This arrangement took effect on January 1, 2010. As a sign of its currently strong cash position, Ford contributed its entire current liability (estimated at approximately US$5.5 billion as of December 31, 2009) to the VEBA in cash, and also pre-paid US$500 million of its future liabilities to the fund. The agreement also gives hourly workers the job security they were seeking by having the company commit to substantial investments in most of its factories.

The automaker reported the largest annual loss in company history in 2006 of $12.7 billion, [[CITE|249|http://money.cnn.com/2007/01/25/news/companies/ford_2006_loss/index.htm]] and estimated that it would not return to profitability until 2009.

[[CITE|5|http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/6298463.stm]] However, Ford surprised [[LINK|lang_en|Wall_Street|Wall Street]] in the second quarter of 2007 by posting a $750 million profit. Despite the gains, the company finished the year with a $2.7 billion loss, largely attributed to finance restructuring at [[LINK|lang_en|Volvo_cars|Volvo]]. [[CITE|41|http://ft.com/cms/s/0/ec11f244-cacc-11dc-a960-000077b07658.html]]

On June 2, 2008, Ford sold its Jaguar and Land Rover operations to [[LINK|lang_en|Tata_Motors|Tata Motors]] for $2.3 billion. [[CITE|55|https://reuters.com/article/ousiv/idUSBMA00084220080602]] [[CITE|70|http://autoweek.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20080630%2FFREE%2F940478590%2F1528%2Fnewsletter01]]
During congressional hearings held in November 2008 at Washington D.C., and in a show of support, Ford's Alan Mulally stated that "We at Ford are hopeful that we have enough liquidity.
But we also must prepare ourselves for the prospect of further deteriorating economic conditions".

Mulally went on to state that "The collapse of one of our competitors would have a severe impact on Ford" and that Ford Motor Company's supports both Chrysler and General Motors in their search for government bridge loans in the face of conditions caused by the [[LINK|lang_en|2007–2012_global_financial_crisis|2008 financial crisis]]. [[CITE|101|https://web.archive.org/web/20131203014300/http://www.banking.senate.gov/public/_files/Mulally0Ford12408FinalWrittenTestimony.pdf?em=]] [[CITE|129|https://npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=97481354]] Together, the three companies presented action plans for the sustainability of the industry. Mulally stated that "In addition to our plan, we are also here today to request support for the industry. In the near-term, Ford does not require access to a government bridge loan. However, we request a credit line of $9 billion as a critical backstop or safeguard against worsening conditions as we drive transformational change in our company"[[CITE|156|https://nytimes.com/2008/11/19/business/19auto.html]] GM and Chrysler received government loans and financing through [[LINK|lang_en|T.A.R.P.|T.A.R.P.]] legislation funding provisions. [[CITE|186|https://nytimes.com/2008/12/19/business/worldbusiness/19iht-auto.4.18831532.html]]

On December 19, the cost of [[LINK|lang_en|Credit_default_swap|credit default swaps]] to insure the debt of Ford was 68 percent the sum insured for five years in addition to annual payments of 5 percent. That meant $6.8 million paid upfront to insure $10 million in debt, in addition to payments of $500,000 per year. [[CITE|204|http://uk.reuters.com/article/rbssConsumerGoodsAndRetailNews/idUKN1944446120081219]] In January 2009, Ford reported a $14.6 billion loss in the preceding year, a record for the company. The company retained sufficient liquidity to fund its operations. Through April 2009, Ford's strategy of debt for equity exchanges erased $9.9 billion in liabilities (28% of its total) in order to leverage its cash position. [[CITE|222|https://wsj.com/articles/SB123902308085992679]] These actions yielded Ford a $2.7 billion profit in fiscal year 2009, the company's first full-year profit in four years. [[CITE|244|https://nytimes.com/2010/01/29/business/29ford.html]] In 2012, Ford's corporate bonds were upgraded from junk to investment grade again, citing sustainable, lasting improvements. [[CITE|263|http://freep.com/article/20120522/BUSINESS0102/120522056/Moody-Ford-credit-upgrade]]
On October 29, 2012, Ford announced the sale of its climate control components business, its last remaining automotive components operation, to Detroit Thermal Systems LLC for an undisclosed price.
[[CITE|2|https://reuters.com/article/2012/10/29/us-ford-valeo-idUSBRE89S05C20121029]]

On November 1, 2012, Ford announced that [[LINK|lang_en|CEO|CEO]] [[LINK|lang_en|Alan_Mulally|Alan Mulally]] will stay with the company until 2014. Ford also named [[LINK|lang_en|Mark_Fields_(businessman)|Mark Fields]], the president of operations in Americas, as its new chief operating officer [[CITE|21|https://nytimes.com/aponline/2012/11/01/us/ap-us-ford-ceo.html]] Ford's CEO Mulally was paid a compensation of over $174 million in his previous seven years at Ford since 2006. The generous amount has been a sore point for some workers of the company. [[CITE|42|http://bigstory.ap.org/article/mulally-puts-focus-back-fords-cars-trucks-0]]
In April 2016, Ford announced a plan to modernize its Dearborn engineering and headquarters campuses through a ten-year building project.
The end result would see the number of Ford employees working in these areas doubling, to 24,000.
During construction, some 2000 of the employees were relocated out of the campus to a temporary location in a disused section of the local shopping mall.
[[CITE|71|https://mlive.com/business/index.ssf/2016/05/ford_and_fairlane_mall.html]] Facilities would also be altered to allow ride-sharing and electric and self-driving vehicles.
[[CITE|94|https://detroitnews.com/story/business/autos/ford/2016/04/12/ford-transform-campus/82935594]] Estimates of the construction cost were $1.2 billion.
[[CITE|119|https://freep.com/story/money/cars/ford/2016/04/12/ford-unveils-redevelopment-plan-dearborn-offices/82904392]]

On January 3, 2017, Ford [[LINK|lang_en|CEO|CEO]] [[LINK|lang_en|Mark_Fields_(businessman)|Mark Fields]] announced that in a "vote of confidence" because of the pro-business climate being fostered in part by [[LINK|lang_en|President-elect_of_the_United_States|President-elect]] [[LINK|lang_en|Donald_Trump|Donald Trump]], Ford has cancelled plans to invest $1.6 billion in a new plant in [[LINK|lang_en|Mexico|Mexico]] to manufacture the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Focus|Ford Focus]]. The [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Focus|Ford Focus]] will now be manufactured in the existing plant in Mexico. Instead, Fields announced that Ford will be investing $700 million in [[LINK|lang_en|Michigan|Michigan]], which it plans to use to create 700 new jobs. [[CITE|142|http://fox2now.com/2017/01/03/ford-cancels-mexico-plant-will-create-700-u-s-jobs-in-vote-of-confidence-in-trump]]
In February 2017, Ford Motor Co. acquired majority ownership of Argo AI, an self-driving car startup.
[[CITE|176|http://foundrymag.com/materials/chinese-automaker-adopts-sintercast-cgi]]
In May 2017, Ford announced cuts to its global workforce amid efforts to address the company's declining share price and to improve profits.
The company is targeting $3 billion in cost reduction and a nearly 10% reduction in the salaried workforce in Asia and North America to enhance earnings in 2018.

[[CITE|176|http://foundrymag.com/materials/chinese-automaker-adopts-sintercast-cgi]] [[CITE|176|http://foundrymag.com/materials/chinese-automaker-adopts-sintercast-cgi]] Jim Hackett was announced to replace Mark Fields as CEO of Ford Motor. Mr. Hackett most recently oversaw the formation of Ford Smart Mobility, a unit responsible for experimenting with car-sharing programs, self-driving ventures and other programs aimed at helping the 114-year-old auto maker better compete with [[LINK|lang_en|Uber_(company)|Uber Technologies Inc.]], [[LINK|lang_en|Alphabet_Inc.|Alphabet Inc.]] and other tech giants looking to edge in on the auto industry. [[CITE|176|http://foundrymag.com/materials/chinese-automaker-adopts-sintercast-cgi]] [[CITE|176|http://foundrymag.com/materials/chinese-automaker-adopts-sintercast-cgi]]

On April 25, 2018, Ford announced that it will discontinue passenger cars in the North American market in the next four years, except for the Mustang and the Focus Active, due to declining demand and profitability.

[[CITE|176|http://foundrymag.com/materials/chinese-automaker-adopts-sintercast-cgi]] But on August 31, 2018, Ford announced that the Focus Active will not go on sale in North America because of the tariffs that would be placed on vehicles built overseas, as the Focus Active is being built in China and later announced in a statement on September 10, 2018 that they have no plans to build it in the United States.
[[CITE|176|http://foundrymag.com/materials/chinese-automaker-adopts-sintercast-cgi]] [[CITE|176|http://foundrymag.com/materials/chinese-automaker-adopts-sintercast-cgi]]

Ford began development on an urban campus in [[LINK|lang_en|Corktown,_Detroit|the Corktown neighborhood of Detroit]] in 2017 with its purchase, renovation and occupation of The Factory building at Michigan and Rosa Parks. [[CITE|176|http://foundrymag.com/materials/chinese-automaker-adopts-sintercast-cgi]] Ford later began buying up other parcels of land in Corktown including a very high-profile purchase of [[LINK|lang_en|Michigan_Central_Station|Michigan Central Station]] which is planned to become the hub of their Corktown campus, and the adjacent [[LINK|lang_en|Roosevelt_Warehouse|Roosevelt Warehouse]]. [[CITE|176|http://foundrymag.com/materials/chinese-automaker-adopts-sintercast-cgi]] Plans for the Corktown campus include 1.2 million square feet of mixed-use development spread over multiple parcels. The focus of the campus will be on [[LINK|lang_en|Autonomous_vehicles|autonomous vehicles]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Electric_vehicles|electric vehicles]] which Ford plans to move aggressively into the development of. Ford expects to move 2,500 of its employees, roughly 5 percent of its southeast Michigan workforce, to the campus with space for an additional 2,500 entrepreneurs, technology companies and partners related to Ford's expansion into Autos 2.0. [[CITE|197|https://forbes.com/sites/joannmuller/2010/12/02/ford-familys-stake-is-smaller-but-theyre-richer-and-remain-firmly-in-control]] Bill Ford said he envisions the first-floor concourse of the train station to be a gathering place, open to the public, filled with restaurants and retail. [[CITE|197|https://forbes.com/sites/joannmuller/2010/12/02/ford-familys-stake-is-smaller-but-theyre-richer-and-remain-firmly-in-control]]

caption.text: [[LINK|lang_en|William_Clay_Ford_Jr.|William Clay Ford Jr.]], great-grandson of Henry Ford, serves as the [[LINK|lang_en|Executive_chairman|executive chairman]] at the board of Ford Motor Company

The historic, once abandoned [[LINK|lang_en|Michigan_Central_Station|Michigan Central Station]] was purchased by Ford Motor Company in May 2018 and is expected to undergo a significant four year renovation.

items.text: Logo evolution
Corporate affairs
Executive management

Members of the Ford board as of October 2018 are: Stephen Butler, [[LINK|lang_en|Kimberly_Casiano|Kimberly Casiano]], Anthony F. Earley, Jr., [[LINK|lang_en|Edsel_Ford_II|Edsel Ford II]], [[LINK|lang_en|William_Clay_Ford_Jr.|William Clay Ford Jr.]] (executive chairman), [[LINK|lang_en|James_Hackett_(businessman)|Jim Hackett]] (president and CEO), William W. Helman IV, [[LINK|lang_en|William_E._Kennard|William E. Kennard]], [[LINK|lang_en|John_C._Lechleiter|John C. Lechleiter]], Ellen Marram, [[LINK|lang_en|John_L._Thornton|John L. Thornton]], [[LINK|lang_en|John_Veihmeyer|John Veihmeyer]], Lynn Vojvodich, and John S. Weinberg. [[CITE|145|https://media.ford.com/content/fordmedia/fna/us/en/people.filter.members-of-the-board.0.100.default_all.html]]
Financial results
In 2010, Ford earned a net profit of $6.6 billion and reduced its debt from $33.6 billion to $14.5 billion lowering interest payments by $1 billion following its 2009 net profit of $2.7 billion.

[[CITE|254|http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/4297305.stm]] [[CITE|177|http://corporate.ford.com/doc/2009_annual_report.pdf]] In the U.S., the F-Series was the best-selling vehicle for 2010. Ford sold 528,349 F-Series trucks during the year, a 27.7% increase over 2009, out of a total sales of 1.9 million vehicles, or every one out of four vehicles Ford sold. Trucks sales accounts for a big slice of Ford's profits, according to USA Today. [[CITE|197|https://forbes.com/sites/joannmuller/2010/12/02/ford-familys-stake-is-smaller-but-theyre-richer-and-remain-firmly-in-control]] In 2017 it is estimated that 90 percent of the company's global profits comes from the Ford F-Series. [[CITE|197|https://forbes.com/sites/joannmuller/2010/12/02/ford-familys-stake-is-smaller-but-theyre-richer-and-remain-firmly-in-control]] Ford's realignment also included the sale of its wholly owned subsidiary, [[LINK|lang_en|The_Hertz_Corporation|Hertz Rent-a-Car]] to a [[LINK|lang_en|Private_equity|private equity]] group for $15 billion in cash and debt acquisition. The sale was completed on December 22, 2005. A 50–50 joint venture with [[LINK|lang_en|Mahindra_&_Mahindra|Mahindra & Mahindra]] of India, called [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_India_Private_Limited|Mahindra Ford India, Limited]] (MIFL), ended with Ford buying out Mahindra's remaining stake in the company in 2005. [[CITE|197|https://forbes.com/sites/joannmuller/2010/12/02/ford-familys-stake-is-smaller-but-theyre-richer-and-remain-firmly-in-control]] Ford had previously upped its stake to 72% in 1998. [[CITE|197|https://forbes.com/sites/joannmuller/2010/12/02/ford-familys-stake-is-smaller-but-theyre-richer-and-remain-firmly-in-control]] Between 2007 and 2012, Ford benefitted from $1.57 billion in local tax incentives. [[CITE|197|https://forbes.com/sites/joannmuller/2010/12/02/ford-familys-stake-is-smaller-but-theyre-richer-and-remain-firmly-in-control]] [[CITE|236|http://ford.com/about-ford/news-announcements/press-releases/press-releases-detail/pr-ford-motor-company-completes-sale-33059]]
For the fiscal year 2017, Ford Motor reported earnings of US$7.602 billion, with an annual revenue of US$156.776 billion, an increase of 3.3% over the previous fiscal cycle.
Ford's shares traded at $10.95 per share in 2017, and its market capitalization was valued at US$35.7 billion in September 2018.
[[CITE|236|http://ford.com/about-ford/news-announcements/press-releases/press-releases-detail/pr-ford-motor-company-completes-sale-33059]]
Ford Motor Company Fund

The Ford Motor Company Fund (also known as Ford Fund, not affiliated with the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Foundation|Ford Foundation]]), based in Dearborn, Michigan, is the philanthropic arm of the Ford Motor Company. [[CITE|91|http://corporate.ford.com/content/dam/corporate/en/company/community/ford-fund/2016-Ford-Fund-Annual-Report.pdf]] Established in 1949 [[CITE|236|http://ford.com/about-ford/news-announcements/press-releases/press-releases-detail/pr-ford-motor-company-completes-sale-33059]] by [[LINK|lang_en|Henry_Ford_II|Henry Ford II]], Ford Fund is a nonprofit corporation financed by contributions from Ford Motor Company. In 2016, Ford Fund contributed $58.9 million to various causes [[CITE|91|http://corporate.ford.com/content/dam/corporate/en/company/community/ford-fund/2016-Ford-Fund-Annual-Report.pdf]] with a focus on education, driving safely and community building.

An important program from Ford Fund is the Ford Driving Skills for Life program, a driver safety program aimed at teens, that was developed together with the Governors Highway Safety Association and safety experts.

[[CITE|236|http://ford.com/about-ford/news-announcements/press-releases/press-releases-detail/pr-ford-motor-company-completes-sale-33059]] The Ford Volunteer Corps allows Ford employees and retirees to sign up for volunteering work on local projects in more than 40 countries.
[[CITE|236|http://ford.com/about-ford/news-announcements/press-releases/press-releases-detail/pr-ford-motor-company-completes-sale-33059]]
Operations

Ford has had manufacturing [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_Ford_factories|operations]] worldwide, including in the United States, Canada, Mexico, China, the United Kingdom, Germany, Turkey, Brazil, Argentina, Australia, and South Africa. Ford also has a cooperative agreement with Russian automaker [[LINK|lang_en|GAZ|GAZ]].
North America
In May 2010, Ford reported that its sales increased 23% for the month, and that 37% of its sales came from fleet sales.

[[CITE|236|http://ford.com/about-ford/news-announcements/press-releases/press-releases-detail/pr-ford-motor-company-completes-sale-33059]] In June 2010, Sales to individual customers at dealerships increased 13% while fleet sales rose by 32%.

[[CITE|236|http://ford.com/about-ford/news-announcements/press-releases/press-releases-detail/pr-ford-motor-company-completes-sale-33059]] In the first seven months of 2010, fleet sales of Ford for the same period rose 35% to 386,000 units while retail sales increase 19%.
[[CITE|224|http://autonews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20100809%2FRETAIL01%2F308099960%2F1401]] Fleet sales account for 39 percent of Chrysler's sales and 31 percent for GM's.
[[CITE|224|http://autonews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=%2F20100809%2FRETAIL01%2F308099960%2F1401]]

caption.text: Ford dealer in [[LINK|lang_en|Garden_City,_New_York|Garden City, New York]], ca. 1930–1945

items.text: Europe

At first, [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Germany|Ford in Germany]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_of_Britain|Ford in Britain]] built different models from one another until the late 1960s, with the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Escort_(Europe)|Ford Escort]] and then the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Capri|Ford Capri]] being common to both companies. Later on, the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Taunus|Ford Taunus]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Cortina|Ford Cortina]] became identical, produced in [[LINK|lang_en|Left_hand_drive|left hand drive]] and right hand drive respectively. Rationalisation of model ranges meant that production of many models in the UK switched to elsewhere in Europe, including Belgium and Spain as well as Germany. The [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Sierra|Ford Sierra]] replaced the Taunus and Cortina in 1982, drawing criticism for its radical aerodynamic styling, which was soon given nicknames, the "Jellymould" and "The Salesman's Spaceship."
In February 2002, Ford ended car production in the UK.

It was the first time in 90 years that Ford cars had not been made in Britain, although production of the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Transit|Transit]] van continued at the company's [[LINK|lang_en|Southampton|Southampton]] facility until mid-2013, engines at [[LINK|lang_en|Bridgend|Bridgend]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Dagenham|Dagenham]], and transmissions at [[LINK|lang_en|Halewood|Halewood]]. Development of European Ford is broadly split between [[LINK|lang_en|Dunton_Wayletts|Dunton]] in Essex (powertrain, Fiesta/Ka, and commercial vehicles) and [[LINK|lang_en|Cologne|Cologne]] (body, chassis, electrical, Focus, Mondeo) in Germany. Ford also produced the [[LINK|lang_en|Thames_Trader|Thames]] range of commercial vehicles, although the use of this brand name was discontinued circa 1965.Elsewhere in continental Europe, Ford assembles the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Mondeo|Mondeo]] range in [[LINK|lang_en|Genk|Genk]] (Belgium), Fiesta in [[LINK|lang_en|Valencia|Valencia]] (Spain) and [[LINK|lang_en|Cologne|Cologne]] (Germany), Ka in Valencia (Spain), Focus in Valencia (Spain), [[LINK|lang_en|Saarlouis|Saarlouis]] (Germany), and [[LINK|lang_en|Vsevolozhsk|Vsevolozhsk]] (Russia). Transit production is in [[LINK|lang_en|İzmit|Kocaeli]] (Turkey), [[LINK|lang_en|Southampton|Southampton]] (UK), and Transit Connect in [[LINK|lang_en|İzmit|Kocaeli]] (Turkey).
Ford also owns a joint-venture production plant in Turkey.

[[LINK|lang_en|Otosan|Ford Otosan]], established in the 1970s, manufactures the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Transit_Connect|Transit Connect]] compact panel van as well as the "Jumbo" and long-wheelbase versions of the full-size Transit. This new production facility was set up near [[LINK|lang_en|İzmit|Kocaeli]] in 2002, and its opening marked the end of Transit assembly in Genk.

Another joint venture plant near [[LINK|lang_en|Setúbal|Setúbal]] in Portugal, set up in collaboration with [[LINK|lang_en|Volkswagen|Volkswagen]], formerly assembled the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Galaxy|Galaxy]] people-carrier as well as its sister ships, the [[LINK|lang_en|Volkswagen_Sharan|VW Sharan]] and [[LINK|lang_en|SEAT_Alhambra|SEAT Alhambra]]. With the introduction of the third generation of the Galaxy, Ford has moved the production of the people-carrier to the Genk plant, with Volkswagen taking over sole ownership of the Setúbal facility.

In 2008, Ford acquired a majority stake in [[LINK|lang_en|Automobile_Craiova|Automobile Craiova]], Romania. Starting 2009, the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Transit_Connect|Ford Transit Connect]] was Ford's first model produced in [[LINK|lang_en|Craiova|Craiova]], followed, in 2012, by low-capacity car engines and a new small class car, the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_B-Max|B-Max]]. [[CITE|253|http://acea.be/images/uploads/files/20110114_PRPC-FINAL-1012.xls]]

Its 1959 [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Anglia|Anglia]] two-door saloon was one of the most quirky-looking small family cars in Europe at the time of its launch, but buyers soon became accustomed to its looks and it was hugely popular with British buyers in particular. It was still selling well when replaced by the more practical [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Escort_(Europe)|Escort]] in 1967.
The third incarnation of the Ford Escort was launched in 1980 and marked the company's move from rear-wheel drive saloons to front-wheel drive hatchbacks in the small family car sector.

The fourth generation Escort was produced from 1990 until 2000, although its successor – the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Focus_(international)|Focus]] – had been on sale since 1998. On its launch, the Focus was arguably the most dramatic-looking and fine-handling small family cars on sale and sold in huge volumes right up to the launch of the next generation Focus at the end of 2004.

The 1982 [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Sierra|Ford Sierra]] – replacement for the long-running and massively popular [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Cortina|Cortina]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Taunus|Taunus]] models – was a style-setter at the time of its launch. Its ultramodern aerodynamic design was a world away from a boxy, sharp-edged Cortina, and it was massively popular just about everywhere it was sold. A series of updates kept it looking relatively fresh until it was replaced by the front-wheel drive [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Mondeo|Mondeo]] at the start of 1993.

The rise in popularity of small cars during the 1970s saw Ford enter the mini-car market in 1976 with its [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Fiesta|Fiesta]] hatchback. Most of its production was concentrated at [[LINK|lang_en|Valencia,_Spain|Valencia]] in Spain, and the Fiesta sold in huge figures from the very start. An update in 1983 and the launch of an all-new model in 1989 strengthened its position in the small car market.

On October 24, 2012, Ford announced that it would be closing its [[LINK|lang_en|Genk|Genk]] assembly plant in eastern [[LINK|lang_en|Belgium|Belgium]] by the end of 2014. [[CITE|253|http://acea.be/images/uploads/files/20110114_PRPC-FINAL-1012.xls]]

In September 2018, at the IAA Commercial Vehicles show in Hannover, Germany, Ford introduced an electric tractor trailer concept vehicle dubbed the F-Vision, which would have Level 4 autonomous driving capability.
[[CITE|253|http://acea.be/images/uploads/files/20110114_PRPC-FINAL-1012.xls]]

caption.text: Ford's [[LINK|lang_en|Dunton_Technical_Centre|Dunton Technical Centre]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Laindon|Laindon]], [[LINK|lang_en|United_Kingdom|United Kingdom]], the largest automotive research and development facility in the country [[CITE|236|http://ford.com/about-ford/news-announcements/press-releases/press-releases-detail/pr-ford-motor-company-completes-sale-33059]]
The Ford Research Center in [[LINK|lang_en|Aachen|Aachen]], [[LINK|lang_en|Germany|Germany]]

items.text: East and Southeast Asia
Ford formed its first passenger-vehicle joint venture in China in 2001, six years behind GM and more than a decade after VW.
It has spent as of 2013 $4.9 billion to expand its lineup and double production capacity in China to 600,000 vehicles.
This includes Ford's largest-ever factory complex in the southwestern city of Chongqing.
Ford had 2.5% of the Chinese market in 2013, while VW controlled 14.5% and GM had 15.6%, according to consultant LMC Automotive.
GM outsells Ford in China by more than six-to-one.

[[CITE|253|http://acea.be/images/uploads/files/20110114_PRPC-FINAL-1012.xls]] Ford's presence in Asia has traditionally been much smaller, confined to [[LINK|lang_en|Malaysia|Malaysia]], Singapore, Hong Kong, the [[LINK|lang_en|Philippines|Philippines]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Taiwan|Taiwan]], where Ford has had a joint venture with [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Lio_Ho_Motor|Lio Ho]] since the 1970s. Ford began assembly of cars in [[LINK|lang_en|Thailand|Thailand]] in 1960, but withdrew from the country in 1976, and did not return until 1995 when it formed a joint venture with [[LINK|lang_en|Mazda|Mazda]] called Auto Alliance. [[CITE|253|http://acea.be/images/uploads/files/20110114_PRPC-FINAL-1012.xls]] Now based in the Bo-win Sub District of the Sriracha District in [[LINK|lang_en|Chonburi_(city)|Chonburi]], the factory still produces passenger automobiles. The factory built in 1941 in Singapore was shortly taken over by the Japanese during the war and was the site of a surrender of the British to the Japanese, at the [[LINK|lang_en|Old_Ford_Motor_Factory|factory site]] which is now a national monument in Singapore.On April 30, 2013, Ford Motor Co. launched their car and truck line in [[LINK|lang_en|Myanmar|Myanmar]]. Previously, heavy importation taxes had stifled imported car purchases in Myanmar, but due to currency reform, lifting of previous import restrictions, and the abolishment of [[LINK|lang_en|Foreign_exchange_controls|shadow currency]], Myanmar's car market had grown in demand. [[CITE|141|http://investvine.com/ford-rolls-into-myanmars-car-market]]
Ford of Korea

In 1967, Ford partnered with the South Korean company [[LINK|lang_en|Hyundai_Motor_Company|Hyundai]], and at the new factory in [[LINK|lang_en|Ulsan,_South_Korea|Ulsan, South Korea]], built the European [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Cortina|Ford Cortina]] until 1974 when Hyundai introduced their all-new [[LINK|lang_en|Hyundai_Pony|Hyundai Pony]] in 1975. Ford then developed a relationship with Korea's oldest car manufacturer [[LINK|lang_en|Kia_Motors|Kia]] which built vehicles co-engineered with [[LINK|lang_en|Mazda|Mazda]], later selling the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Festiva|Ford Festiva]] from 1988–1993, and the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Festiva|Ford Aspire]] from 1994–1997 for export to the United States. With the acquisition of a stake in Japanese manufacturer [[LINK|lang_en|Mazda|Mazda]] in 1979, Ford began selling Mazda's [[LINK|lang_en|Mazda_Familia|Familia]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Mazda_Capella|Capella]] as the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Laser|Ford Laser]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Telstar|Telstar]] throughout the region, replacing the European-sourced Escort and Cortina. Ford lost their Kia interest to Hyundai in 1998 during the [[LINK|lang_en|Asian_financial_crisis|Asian financial crisis]]. Kia had declared bankruptcy in 1997; in 1998, [[LINK|lang_en|Hyundai_Motor_Company|Hyundai Motor Company]] acquired 51% of the company, outbidding Ford which had owned an interest in Kia Motors since 1986. [[CITE|253|http://acea.be/images/uploads/files/20110114_PRPC-FINAL-1012.xls]] After subsequent divestments, [[CITE|253|http://acea.be/images/uploads/files/20110114_PRPC-FINAL-1012.xls]] Hyundai Motor Company owns less than 50% of the company but remains Kia's largest stakeholder.
Ford currently sells the Focus and Mondeo with diesel engines, plus the Mustang, Taurus, Escape, and Explorer, as well as the Lincoln MKS, MKZ, and MKC.
[[CITE|253|http://acea.be/images/uploads/files/20110114_PRPC-FINAL-1012.xls]]
South and West Asia

[[LINK|lang_en|Ford_India_Private_Limited|Ford India]] began production in 1998 at [[LINK|lang_en|Chennai|Chennai]], [[LINK|lang_en|Tamil_Nadu|Tamil Nadu]], with its Ford Escort model, which was later replaced by the locally produced [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Ikon|Ford Ikon]] in 2001. It has since added the Fusion, Fiesta, Mondeo and Endeavour models to its product line.
On March 9, 2010, Ford Motor Co. launched its first made-for-India compact car.

Starting at [[LINK|lang_en|Indian_rupee|₹]] 349,900, the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Figo|Figo]] was Ford's first car designed and priced for the mass Indian market. [[CITE|253|http://acea.be/images/uploads/files/20110114_PRPC-FINAL-1012.xls]] On July 28, 2011, Ford India signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) with the State of [[LINK|lang_en|Gujarat|Gujarat]] for the construction of an assembly and engine plant in [[LINK|lang_en|Sanand|Sanand]] and planned to invest approximately US$1 billion on a 460-acre site. [[CITE|8|https://forbes.com/sites/joannmuller/2014/03/09/william-clay-fords-legacy-cemented-familys-dynasty]]
Ford's market presence in the Middle East has traditionally been small, partly due to previous Arab boycotts of companies dealing with Israel.
Ford and Lincoln vehicles are currently marketed in ten countries in the region.

[[CITE|8|https://forbes.com/sites/joannmuller/2014/03/09/william-clay-fords-legacy-cemented-familys-dynasty]] [[LINK|lang_en|Saudi_Arabia|Saudi Arabia]], Kuwait, and the [[LINK|lang_en|United_Arab_Emirates|United Arab Emirates]] are the biggest markets. Ford also established itself in [[LINK|lang_en|Egypt|Egypt]] in 1926 but faced an uphill battle during the 1950s due to the hostile nationalist business environment. [[CITE|8|https://forbes.com/sites/joannmuller/2014/03/09/william-clay-fords-legacy-cemented-familys-dynasty]] Ford's distributor in Saudi Arabia announced in February 2003 that it had sold 100,000 Ford and Lincoln vehicles since commencing sales in November 1986. Half of the Ford and Lincoln vehicles sold in that country were [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Crown_Victoria|Ford Crown Victorias]]. [[CITE|8|https://forbes.com/sites/joannmuller/2014/03/09/william-clay-fords-legacy-cemented-familys-dynasty]] In 2004, Ford sold 30,000 units in the region, falling far short of [[LINK|lang_en|General_Motors|General Motors]]' 88,852 units and [[LINK|lang_en|Nissan|Nissan Motors]]' 75,000 units.
South America

In South America, Ford's primary operations are in [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Brasil|Brazil]], [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Motor_Argentina|Argentina]], and Ford Andina [[CITE|8|https://forbes.com/sites/joannmuller/2014/03/09/william-clay-fords-legacy-cemented-familys-dynasty]] (Colombia, Ecuador, and Venezuela). Ford employs over 18,000 people and operates seven assembly or other plants in the region. [[CITE|8|https://forbes.com/sites/joannmuller/2014/03/09/william-clay-fords-legacy-cemented-familys-dynasty]] In 1987, Ford Brasil and Ford Motor Argentina merged their operations with the Brazilian and Argentine operations of [[LINK|lang_en|Volkswagen_Group|Volkswagen Group]], forming a new joint-venture company called [[LINK|lang_en|Autolatina|Autolatina]] with a shared model range. [[CITE|146|http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/fsp/1994/12/02/dinheiro/16.html]] Autolatina was dissolved in 1995. [[CITE|146|http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/fsp/1994/12/02/dinheiro/16.html]]
Africa
In Africa, Ford's market presence has traditionally been strongest in South Africa and neighbouring countries, with only trucks being sold elsewhere on the continent.
Ford in South Africa began by importing kits from Canada to be assembled at its Port Elizabeth facility.

Later Ford sourced its models from the UK and Australia, with local versions of the Ford Cortina including the XR6, with a 3.0 V6 engine, and a [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_P100|Cortina-based 'bakkie' or pick-up]], which was exported to the UK. In the mid-1980s, Ford merged with a rival company, owned by [[LINK|lang_en|Anglo_American_plc|Anglo American]], to form the [[LINK|lang_en|South_African_Motor_Corporation|South African Motor Corporation]] ([[LINK|lang_en|Samcor|Samcor]]). [[CITE|8|https://forbes.com/sites/joannmuller/2014/03/09/william-clay-fords-legacy-cemented-familys-dynasty]]

Following international condemnation of [[LINK|lang_en|Apartheid|apartheid]], Ford divested from South Africa in 1988, and sold its stake in Samcor, although it licensed the use of its brand name to the company. [[CITE|8|https://forbes.com/sites/joannmuller/2014/03/09/william-clay-fords-legacy-cemented-familys-dynasty]] Samcor began to assemble Mazdas as well, which affected its product line-up and saw the European Fords like the Escort and Sierra replaced by the [[LINK|lang_en|Mazda|Mazda]]-based Laser [[CITE|8|https://forbes.com/sites/joannmuller/2014/03/09/william-clay-fords-legacy-cemented-familys-dynasty]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Telstar|Telstar]]. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] Ford bought a 45 per cent stake in [[LINK|lang_en|Samcor|Samcor]] following the demise of apartheid in 1994, and this later became, once again, a wholly owned subsidiary, the Ford Motor Company of Southern Africa. Ford now sells a local sedan version of the Fiesta (also built in India and Mexico), and the Focus. The Falcon model from Australia was also sold in South Africa but was dropped in 2003 while the Mondeo, after briefly being assembled locally, was dropped in 2005. The Mondeo was later reintroduced in 2015, badged as the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Fusion_(Americas)|Fusion]] but was dropped in 2017. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]
Former operations
East and Southeast Asia

Ford decided to shut down their entire operations in [[LINK|lang_en|Indonesia|Indonesia]], including their dealer network by second half of 2016. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]
Ford of Japan

Ford established a manufacturing facility in the port city of Yokohama in February 1925, where Model T vehicles were assembled using imported [[LINK|lang_en|Knock-down_kit|knock-down kits]]. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] The factory subsequently produced 10,000 Model A's up to 1936. Production ceased in 1940 as a result of political tensions between Japan and the United States.

After World War II, Ford did not have a presence in Japan, as the Ford facility was appropriated by the Japanese Government until 1958 when property was returned as a possession of the Ford Motor Company and became a [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_Mazda_facilities#R&D|research and development location]] for Ford partner [[LINK|lang_en|Mazda|Mazda]]. In 1979, Ford acquired a 24.5% ownership stake in Mazda, and in 1982, Ford and Mazda jointly established a sales channel to sell Ford products in Japan, including vehicles manufactured in North America, at a dealership called *[[LINK|lang_en|https:|Autorama]] (Japanese)*. The Autorama sales channel was renamed Ford Sales of Japan in 1997. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]
Vehicles sold at *Autorama* locations were the North American assembled Ford Explorer, Probe (1989–1998), Mustang, Taurus (1989–1997), Thunderbird (1990–1993), Lincoln Continental, and Lincoln LS.

Ford products manufactured in Europe that were sold in Japan were the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Mondeo|Ford Mondeo]], [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Ka|Ka]], [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Focus|Focus]], [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_C-Max|Focus C-MAX]], [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Fiesta|Fiesta]], and the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Galaxy|Galaxy]]. Mazda manufactured Ford vehicles in Japan and sold them as Fords at the Autorama locations. They were the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Telstar|Ford Telstar]] (Mazda Capella), [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Laser|Laser]], [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Festiva|Festiva]], [[LINK|lang_en|Mazda_Demio|Festiva Mini Wagon]], [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Ixion|Ixion]] (Mazda Premacy), [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Freda|Freda]] (Mazda Bongo Friendee), [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Spectron|Spectron]] (Mazda Bongo), and commercial trucks J80 and the J100 (Mazda Bongo truck).
Ford increased its shareholding in Mazda to 33.4% in 1996, but as of July 2016, it is listed at 11%.

[[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] Ford did sell a small range of vehicles in Japan; as of October 2010, the Ford Mustang, Escape, Explorer (and Explorer truck), [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Kuga|Ford Kuga]], [[LINK|lang_en|Lincoln_Navigator|Lincoln Navigator]], [[LINK|lang_en|Lincoln_MKX|Lincoln MKX]], and more recently, the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Ecosport|Ford Ecosport]] were available in Japan. As of February 2016, Ford no longer maintains a regional office in Minato, Tokyo, Japan, and sales of new cars in Japan have ended. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]
Oceania

In Australia and New Zealand, the popular [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Falcon_(Australia)|Ford Falcon]] (1960–2016) had long been considered the average family car and is considerably larger than the Mondeo, Ford's largest car sold in Europe. Between 1960 and 1972, the Falcon was based on a U.S. model of the same name, but since then has been entirely designed and manufactured in Australia until 2016, occasionally being manufactured in New Zealand. Like its [[LINK|lang_en|General_Motors|General Motors]] rival, the [[LINK|lang_en|Holden_Commodore|Holden Commodore]], the Falcon used a rear wheel drive layout. High-performance variants of the Falcon running locally built engines produce up to 362 hp (270 kW). A [[LINK|lang_en|Coupé_utility|ute]] (short for "utility", known in the US as [[LINK|lang_en|Pickup_truck|pickup truck]]) version is also available with the same range of drivetrains. In addition, Ford Australia sells highly tuned limited-production Falcon sedans and [[LINK|lang_en|Pickup_truck|utes]] through its performance car division, [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Performance_Vehicles|Ford Performance Vehicles]] until it closed in 2014.
In Australia, the Commodore and Falcon had traditionally outsold all other cars and comprise over 20% of the new car market.
In New Zealand, Ford was second in market share in the first eight months of 2006 with 14.4%.
[[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] More recently, Ford has axed its Falcon-based LWB variant of its lineup– the Fairlane and LTD ranges.
Ford discontinued the Fairlane in 2007 and LTD in 2008.
Ford had announced that their Geelong engine manufacturing plant would be shut down between 2013 and 2016.
They have also announced local manufacturing of the Focus small car starting from 2011, nothing came of that plan.

In Australia, the Laser was one of [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Motor_Company_of_Australia|Ford Australia]]'s most successful models and was manufactured in Ford's [[LINK|lang_en|Homebush,_New_South_Wales|Homebush]] plant from 1981 until the plant's closure in September 1994. It outsold the [[LINK|lang_en|Mazda_323|Mazda 323]], despite being almost identical to it because the Laser was manufactured in Australia and Ford was perceived as a local brand. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] According to research carried out by [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Australia|Ford Australia]] in 1984, a third of Laser buyers were unaware that the Ford model was based on the [[LINK|lang_en|Mazda_323|Mazda 323]]. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]

In New Zealand, the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Laser|Ford Laser]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Telstar|Telstar]] were assembled alongside the [[LINK|lang_en|Mazda_323|Mazda 323]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Mazda_626|626]] until 1997, at the Vehicle Assemblers of New Zealand (VANZ) plant in [[LINK|lang_en|Wiri|Wiri]], [[LINK|lang_en|Auckland|Auckland]]. The [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Sierra|Sierra]] wagon was also assembled in New Zealand, owing to the popularity of [[LINK|lang_en|Station_wagon|station wagons]] in that market.
The scheduled closure of Ford's Australian manufacturing base in 2016 was confirmed on May 23, 2013.
Headquartered in the Victorian suburb of Broadmeadows, the company had registered losses worth AU$600 million over the five years prior to the announcement.

It was noted that the corporate fleet and government sales that account for two-thirds of large, local car sales in Australia are insufficient to keep Ford's products profitable and viable in Australia.
The decision will affect 1200 Ford workers—over 600 employees in Geelong and more than 500 in Broadmeadows—who will lose their jobs by October 2016.
The closure of Fords plants in Norlane Geelong and Broadmeadows Melbourne occurred on October 7, 2016.
[[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]

caption.text: Ford FG X Falcon (Australia) (2014–2016; 2014 model shown)
The Ford stamping plant in [[LINK|lang_en|Geelong|Geelong]], Victoria, Australia. It closed in 2016.

items.text: Products and services
Automobiles

Ford Motor Company sells a broad range of automobiles under the Ford marque worldwide, and an additional range of luxury automobiles under the [[LINK|lang_en|Lincoln_(automobile)|Lincoln]] marque in the United States. The company has sold vehicles under a number of other marques during its history. The [[LINK|lang_en|Mercury_(automobile)|Mercury]] brand was introduced by Ford in 1939, continuing in production until 2011 when poor sales led to its discontinuation. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] In 1958, Ford introduced the [[LINK|lang_en|Edsel|Edsel]] brand, but poor sales led to its discontinuation in 1960. In 1985, the [[LINK|lang_en|Merkur|Merkur]] brand was introduced in the United States to market products produced by Ford of Europe; it was discontinued in 1989.

Ford acquired the British sports car maker [[LINK|lang_en|Aston_Martin|Aston Martin]] in 1989, later selling it on March 12, 2007, [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] although retaining an 8% stake. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] Ford purchased [[LINK|lang_en|Volvo_Cars|Volvo Cars]] of Sweden in 1999, [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] selling it to [[LINK|lang_en|Zhejiang_Geely_Holding_Group|Zhejiang Geely Holding Group]] in 2010. In November 2008, it reduced its 33.4% [[LINK|lang_en|Controlling_interest|controlling interest]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Mazda|Mazda]] of Japan to a 13.4% non-controlling interest. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]
On November 18, 2010, Ford reduced their stake further to just 3%, citing the reduction of ownership would allow greater flexibility to pursue growth in emerging markets.

Ford and Mazda remain strategic partners through exchanges of technological information and joint ventures, including an American joint venture plant in Flat Rock, Michigan called [[LINK|lang_en|Auto_Alliance|Auto Alliance]]. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] Ford sold the United Kingdom-based [[LINK|lang_en|Jaguar_Cars|Jaguar]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Land_Rover|Land Rover]] companies and brands to [[LINK|lang_en|Tata_Motors|Tata Motors]] of India in March 2008. In 2015, Ford sold its remaining 3% stake in Mazda. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]

On April 25, 2018, Ford announced that it planned to phase out the majority of its automobile lineup in North America, besides the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Mustang|Mustang]], to focus primarily on trucks and SUVs. Ford had also planned to introduce a "Active" crossover version of the next-generation [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Focus|Focus]], but canceled those plans due to tariff issues between the United States and China. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]

caption.text: The 2013 model year [[LINK|lang_en|Lincoln_MKS|Lincoln MKS]]

items.text: Former marques
Trucks

Ford has produced trucks since 1908, beginning with the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Model_TT|Ford Model TT]], followed by the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Model_AA|Model AA]], and the [[LINK|lang_en|1932_Ford#Model_BB_trucks|Model BB]]. Countries where Ford commercial vehicles are or were formerly produced include Argentina, Australia, Brazil, Canada (also badged as [[LINK|lang_en|Mercury_(automobile)|Mercury]]), France, Germany, India, Netherlands, Philippines, Spain (badged [[LINK|lang_en|Ebro_trucks|Ebro]] too), Turkey, UK (badged also [[LINK|lang_en|Fordson|Fordson]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Thames_Trader|Thames]]), and the United States.
From the 1940s to late 1970s, Ford's [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_F-Series|Ford F-Series]] were used as the base for light trucks for the North American market.
Most of these ventures are now extinct.

The European one that lasted longest was the lorries arm of [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_of_Britain|Ford of Britain]], which became part of the [[LINK|lang_en|Iveco|Iveco]] group in 1986. Ford had a minority share in the new company and Iveco took over sales and production of the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Cargo|Ford Cargo]] range. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] Ford's last significant European truck models were the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Transcontinental|Transcontinental]] and the Cargo.

At the end of 1996, Ford sold the rights to its heavy trucks division to the [[LINK|lang_en|Freightliner_Trucks|Freightliner Trucks]] division of Daimler AG, with Ford producing the Cargo, Louisville, and Aeromax, through the 1998 model year. During the 1998 model year, Freightliner began production of its own versions of Ford-developed trucks in St. Thomas, Ontario, launching the [[LINK|lang_en|Sterling_Trucks|Sterling]] truck brand. [[CITE|65|http://daimler.com/dccom/0-5-7153-1-1137391-1-0-0-0-0-0-8-7145-0-0-0-0-0-0-1.html]] [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] Slotted between Freightliner and Western Star, Sterling trucks were produced through 2009.
Line of heavy trucks made by Ford for the North American market:

sentences.text: Ford F-Series "Super Duty/Extra Heavy Duty (1958-1962) "Big Job" (1951-1957)
[[LINK|lang_en|Ford_L-Series|Ford L-Series trucks]] (1970-1998) aka Ford "Louisville Line" Ford Aeromax (1988-1998) Ford Louisville (1996-1998) Sterling (1998-2009)

items.text: For 1999, Ford briefly withdrew from production of medium-duty trucks.

For the 2001 model year, the company entered into a joint venture with [[LINK|lang_en|Navistar_International|Navistar International]] (the supplier of diesel engines for 1-ton F-Series trucks), named *Blue Diamond Truck Company LLC*. [[CITE|97|https://ford-trucks.com/articles/08-07-2001-ford-navistar-join-forces-to-create-blue-diamond-truck-company]] As part of the joint venture, sharing a common truck chassis, the two companies would produce medium-duty (Class 6-7) trucks in a Navistar facility in Mexico, with each manufacturer supplying its own powertrain and bodywork, with the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_F-650|Ford F-650/F-750 Super Duty]] and [[LINK|lang_en|International_DuraStar|International 4000/DuraStar]] sharing an assembly line. In 2006, the joint venture debuted the Ford LCF/International CityStar. [[CITE|115|http://trailer-bodybuilders.com/mag/trucks_ford_enters_lcf]] Using a modified F-Series chassis adopted to fit a Mazda Titan cab, the LCF was a low-cab forward truck that was sold through 2009. [[CITE|153|http://fordtrucksonline.com/new-ford-low-cab-forward-specs.htm]]

In Europe, Ford manufactures the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Transit|Ford Transit]] jumbo van which is classed as a Large Goods Vehicle and has a payload of up to 2,265 kg, there are options of a panel van, pickup or chassis cab. The Ford Transit is also available as a light van called the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Transit_Connect|Ford Transit Connect]] and the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Ranger|Ford Ranger]] pickup is available. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]

caption.text: An advertisement for the 1939 Ford V-8 pick-up truck
An advertisement for the 1961 Ford H-Series truck

items.text: Buses

Ford manufactured complete buses in the company's early history, but today the role of the company has changed to that of a [[LINK|lang_en|Second_stage_manufacturer|second stage manufacturer]]. In North America, the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_E-Series|E-Series]] is still used as a chassis for small school buses and the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_F-650|F-650]] is used in commercial bus markets. In the 1980s and 1990s, the medium-duty [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_B-Series|B700]] was a popular chassis used by school bus body manufacturers including [[LINK|lang_en|Thomas_Built_Buses|Thomas Built]], [[LINK|lang_en|Ward_Body_Works|Ward]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Blue_Bird_Corporation|Blue Bird]], but Ford lost its market share due to industry contraction and agreements between body manufacturers. Older bus models included:
Prior to 1936, Ford buses were based on truck bodies:

In 1936, Ford introduced the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Transit_Bus|Ford Transit Bus]], a series of small transit buses with bodies built by a second party. Originally a front-engine design, it was modified to a rear-engine design in 1939. About 1,000 to 1,200 of the original design were built, and around 12,500 of the rear-engine design, which was in production until 1947 [[CITE|212|http://worldcat.org/issn/0739-117X]] (rebranded as the Universal Bus in 1946).
Rear-engine Transit Bus chassis model numbers: [[CITE|229|http://detroittransithistory.info/PhotoGalley/Photos1940sA.html]]
After 1946 the Transit City bus was sold as the *Universal Bus* with the roof changed from fabric/wood to all-metal:
Succeeding the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Transit_Bus|Ford Transit Bus]] was the Ford 8M buses:

Following World War II and from 1950s onwards, Ford lost out to [[LINK|lang_en|General_Motors|General Motors]]. [[CITE|229|http://detroittransithistory.info/PhotoGalley/Photos1940sA.html]] This led to the end of transit buses for Ford in North America.

sentences.text: [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_B-Series|B500 or B-series]] – 1950–1990s based on Ford F-series truck chassis used by school bus body manufacturers

items.text: In Europe, Ford manufactures the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Transit|Ford Transit]] [[LINK|lang_en|Minibus|Minibus]] which is classed in Europe as a Passenger Carrying Vehicle and there are options of 12-, 15-, or 17-seaters. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] In the past, European models included:
