items.text: Tractors

The "Henry Ford and Son Company" began making [[LINK|lang_en|Fordson_tractor|Fordson tractors]] in Henry's hometown of Springwells (later part of [[LINK|lang_en|Dearborn,_Michigan|Dearborn]]), Michigan from 1907 to 1928, from 1919 to 1932, at [[LINK|lang_en|Cork_(city)|Cork]], Ireland, and 1933–1964 at [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Dagenham|Dagenham]], England, later transferred to [[LINK|lang_en|Basildon|Basildon]]. They were also produced in [[LINK|lang_en|Leningrad|Leningrad]] beginning in 1924.

In 1986, Ford expanded its tractor business when it purchased the Sperry-New Holland skid-steer loader and hay baler, hay tools and implement company from [[LINK|lang_en|Sperry_Corporation|Sperry Corporation]] and formed Ford-New Holland which bought out [[LINK|lang_en|Versatile_(company)|Versatile]] tractors in 1988. This company was bought by [[LINK|lang_en|Fiat|Fiat]] in 1993 and the name changed from Ford New Holland to New Holland. [[LINK|lang_en|New_Holland_Ag|New Holland]] is now part of [[LINK|lang_en|CNH_Global|CNH Global]].

caption.text: A Ford N series tractor

items.text: Financial services
Ford offers automotive finance through [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Motor_Credit_Company|Ford Motor Credit Company]].
Automotive components
Ford's *FoMoCo* parts division sells aftermarket parts under the [[LINK|lang_en|Motorcraft|Motorcraft]] brand name. It has spun off its parts division under the name [[LINK|lang_en|Visteon|Visteon]].
Motorsport

Along with [[LINK|lang_en|Carroll_Shelby_International|Shelby]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Chevrolet|Chevrolet]], Ford is one of only three American constructors to win titles on the international scene at the [[LINK|lang_en|Fédération_Internationale_de_l'Automobile|FIA]] [[LINK|lang_en|List_of_world_championships#Open|World Championships]]. As a constructor, Ford won the [[LINK|lang_en|World_Sportscar_Championship|World Sportscar Championship]] three times in [[LINK|lang_en|1966_World_Sportscar_Championship_season|1966]], [[LINK|lang_en|1967_World_Sportscar_Championship_season|1967]], and [[LINK|lang_en|1968_World_Sportscar_Championship_season|1968]], and the [[LINK|lang_en|World_Rally_Championship|World Rally Championship]] three times in [[LINK|lang_en|1979_World_Rally_Championship_season|1979]], [[LINK|lang_en|2006_World_Rally_Championship_season|2006]] and [[LINK|lang_en|2007_World_Rally_Championship_season|2007]].
Open-wheel car racing
IndyCar

[[LINK|lang_en|American_open-wheel_car_racing|IndyCars]] with Ford engines first competed in 1935 using a [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_flathead_V8_engine|production-based Ford V8]] in the Miller-Ford racer. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] A [[LINK|lang_en|Overhead_valve_engine|pushrod]] Ford V8 raced with Lotus in 1963, and Ford's first Indy win was in 1965 with a [[LINK|lang_en|Overhead_camshaft#Dual_overhead_camshaft|DOHC]] V8. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] Ford motors, including the Ford-sponsored [[LINK|lang_en|Cosworth_DFV#DFX|DFX engine]] developed by [[LINK|lang_en|Cosworth|Cosworth]], have won the [[LINK|lang_en|Indianapolis_500|Indianapolis 500]] eighteen times. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] On May 12, 1996, [[LINK|lang_en|Arie_Luyendyk|Arie Luyendyk]], while driving an IndyCar powered by a Ford Cosworth XB engine, broke the [[LINK|lang_en|Indianapolis_500_records|Indianapolis 500 records]] for fastest qualification lap (237.498 mph (382.216 km/h)) and fastest qualification four-lap average (236.986 mph (381.392 km/h)). [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] These speed records still stand as of 2018. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]

caption.text: Arie Luyendyk's record-setting Ford Cosworth-powered IndyCar from 1996

items.text: Formula Ford

[[LINK|lang_en|Formula_Ford|Formula Ford]], conceived in the UK in 1966, is an entry-level type of [[LINK|lang_en|Formula_racing|formula racing]] with wingless single-seater cars. Many of today's formula racing drivers started their car racing careers in this category.
Formula One

Ford was heavily involved in [[LINK|lang_en|Formula_One|Formula One]] for many years and supplied engines to a large number of teams from 1967 until 2004. These engines were designed and manufactured by [[LINK|lang_en|Cosworth|Cosworth]], the racing division that was owned by Ford from 1998 to 2004. Ford-badged engines won 176 Grands Prix between 1967 and 2003 for teams such as [[LINK|lang_en|Team_Lotus|Team Lotus]] and [[LINK|lang_en|McLaren|McLaren]]. Ford entered Formula One as a constructor in 2000 under the [[LINK|lang_en|Jaguar_Racing|Jaguar Racing]] name, after buying the [[LINK|lang_en|Stewart_Grand_Prix|Stewart Grand Prix]] team which had been its primary 'works' team in the series since 1997. Jaguar achieved little success in Formula One, and after a turbulent five seasons, Ford withdrew from the category after the [[LINK|lang_en|2004_Formula_One_season|2004 season]], selling both Jaguar Racing (which became [[LINK|lang_en|Red_Bull_Racing|Red Bull Racing]]) and Cosworth (to [[LINK|lang_en|Gerald_Forsythe|Gerald Forsythe]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Kevin_Kalkhoven|Kevin Kalkhoven]]). [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]
Stock car racing

Ford is one of three manufacturers in [[LINK|lang_en|NASCAR|NASCAR]]'s three major series: [[LINK|lang_en|Monster_Energy_NASCAR_Cup_Series|Monster Energy NASCAR Cup Series]], [[LINK|lang_en|Xfinity_Series|Xfinity Series]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Camping_World_Truck_Series|Camping World Truck Series]]. Major teams include [[LINK|lang_en|Roush_Fenway_Racing|Roush Fenway Racing]], [[LINK|lang_en|Team_Penske|Team Penske]], [[LINK|lang_en|Stewart-Haas_Racing|Stewart-Haas Racing]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Wood_Brothers_Racing|Wood Brothers Racing]]. Ford is represented by the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Mustang|Mustang]] in the Monster Energy Cup Series, and the Xfinity Series and by the [[LINK|lang_en|F-150|F-150]] in the Camping World Truck Series. Some of the most successful NASCAR Fords were the aerodynamic fastback [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Torino|Ford Torino]], [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Torino_Talladega|Ford Torino Talladega]], [[LINK|lang_en|Mercury_Cyclone_Spoiler_II|Mercury Cyclone Spoiler II]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Mercury_Montego|Mercury Montegos]], and the aero-era [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Thunderbird|Ford Thunderbirds]]. The Ford nameplate has won eight [[LINK|lang_en|Sprint_Cup_Series#Manufacturer's_Championship|manufacturer's championships]] in Sprint Cup while Mercury has won one. In the Sprint Cup Series, Ford earned its 1,000th victory in the [[LINK|lang_en|2013_Quicken_Loans_400|2013 Quicken Loans 400]]. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] The Ford Fusion is also used in the [[LINK|lang_en|ARCA_Racing_Series|ARCA Racing Series]]. Ford had last won a drivers' championship in the Cup Series with [[LINK|lang_en|Joey_Logano|Joey Logano]] in 2018.

caption.text: [[LINK|lang_en|Ryan_Blaney|Ryan Blaney]] driving the iconic No. 21 Wood Brothers Ford in 2016 at [[LINK|lang_en|Michigan_International_Speedway|Michigan International Speedway]]

items.text: Rally

Ford has a long history in [[LINK|lang_en|Rallying|rallying]] and has been active in the [[LINK|lang_en|World_Rally_Championship|World Rally Championship]] since the beginning of the world championship, the [[LINK|lang_en|1973_World_Rally_Championship_season|1973 season]]. Ford took the [[LINK|lang_en|1979_World_Rally_Championship_season|1979]] manufacturers' title with [[LINK|lang_en|Hannu_Mikkola|Hannu Mikkola]], [[LINK|lang_en|Björn_Waldegård|Björn Waldegård]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Ari_Vatanen|Ari Vatanen]] driving the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Escort_RS1800|Ford Escort RS1800]]. In the [[LINK|lang_en|Group_B|Group B]] era, Ford achieved success with [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_RS200|Ford RS200]]. Since the [[LINK|lang_en|1999_World_Rally_Championship_season|1999 season]], Ford has used various versions of the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Focus_WRC|Ford Focus WRC]] to much success. In the [[LINK|lang_en|2006_World_Rally_Championship_season|2006 season]], [[LINK|lang_en|BP-Ford_World_Rally_Team|BP-Ford World Rally Team]] secured Ford its second manufacturers' title, with the Focus RS WRC 06 built by [[LINK|lang_en|M-Sport|M-Sport]] and driven by "[[LINK|lang_en|Flying_Finns|Flying Finns]]"[[LINK|lang_en|Marcus_Grönholm|Marcus Grönholm]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Mikko_Hirvonen|Mikko Hirvonen]]. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] Continuing with Grönholm and Hirvonen, Ford successfully defended the manufacturers' world championship in the [[LINK|lang_en|2007_World_Rally_Championship_season|2007 season]]. Ford is the only manufacturer to score in the points for 92 consecutive races; since the [[LINK|lang_en|2002_World_Rally_Championship_season|2002 season]] opener [[LINK|lang_en|Monte_Carlo_Rally|Monte Carlo Rally]]. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]

caption.text: [[LINK|lang_en|Jari-Matti_Latvala|Jari-Matti Latvala]] driving the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Focus_RS_WRC_09|Ford Focus RS WRC 09]] in 2010

items.text: Rallycross

Ford has competed in rallycross with its [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Fiesta|Ford Fiesta]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Focus|Ford Focus]]. [[LINK|lang_en|Tanner_Foust|Tanner Foust]] won the [[LINK|lang_en|Global_RallyCross_Championship|Global RallyCross Championship]] in 2011 and 2012 and was runner-up in the [[LINK|lang_en|FIA_European_Rallycross_Championship|FIA European Rallycross Championship]] in 2011 and 2012. [[LINK|lang_en|Toomas_Heikkinen|Toomas Heikkinen]] won the Global RallyCross Championship title in 2013 and [[LINK|lang_en|Joni_Wiman|Joni Wiman]] won it in 2014. Other notable Ford drivers include [[LINK|lang_en|Marcus_Grönholm|Marcus Grönholm]], [[LINK|lang_en|Ken_Block|Ken Block]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Brian_Deegan_(rider)|Brian Deegan]].
Sports cars
Ford sports cars have been visible in the world of sports car racing since 1964.

Most notably the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_GT40|GT40]] won the [[LINK|lang_en|24_Hours_of_Le_Mans|24 Hours of Le Mans]] four times in the 1960s and is the only American car to ever win overall at this prestigious event. Ford also won the [[LINK|lang_en|1968_World_Sportscar_Championship_season|1968 International Championship for Makes]] with the GT40, which still stands today as one of the all-time greatest racing cars. Swiss team [[LINK|lang_en|Matech_Concepts|Matech GT Racing]], in collaboration with Ford Racing, opened a new chapter with the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_GT|Ford GT]], winning the Teams title in the 2008 [[LINK|lang_en|FIA_GT3_European_Championship|FIA GT3 European Championship]].

The [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Mustang|Ford Mustang]] has arguably been Ford's most successful sports car. [[LINK|lang_en|Jerry_Titus|Jerry Titus]] won the 1965 SCCA Pro B National Championship with a Mustang and the model went on to earn Ford the SCCA [[LINK|lang_en|Trans-Am_Series|Trans-Am Championship]] title in both 1966 and 1967. Ford won the Trans-Am Championship again in 1970 with [[LINK|lang_en|Parnelli_Jones|Parnelli Jones]] and [[LINK|lang_en|George_Follmer|George Follmer]] driving [[LINK|lang_en|Boss_302_Mustang|Boss 302 Mustangs]] for [[LINK|lang_en|Bud_Moore_Engineering|Bud Moore Engineering]]. Ford took the 1985 and 1986 [[LINK|lang_en|IMSA_GT_Championship|IMSA GTO Championship]] with Mustangs driven by [[LINK|lang_en|John_Jones_(racing_driver)|John Jones]] and [[LINK|lang_en|Scott_Pruett|Scott Pruett]] before returning to Trans-Am glory with a championship in 1989 with [[LINK|lang_en|Dorsey_Schroeder|Dorsey Schroeder]]. Ford dominated Trans-Am in the 1990s with [[LINK|lang_en|Tommy_Kendall|Tommy Kendall]] winning championships in 1993, 1995, 1996, and 1997 with [[LINK|lang_en|Paul_Gentilozzi|Paul Gentilozzi]] adding yet another title in 1999. In 2005 the Ford Mustang FR500C took the championship in the Rolex [[LINK|lang_en|IMSA_Continental_Tire_Sports_Car_Challenge|Koni Challenge]] Series in its first year on the circuit. In 2007, Ford added a victory in the GT4 European Championship. 2008 was the first year of the Mustang Challenge for the Miller Cup, a series which pits a full field of identical factory-built Ford Mustang race cars against each other. Also, in 2008, Ford won the manufacturers championship in the [[LINK|lang_en|IMSA_Continental_Tire_Sports_Car_Challenge|Koni Challenge]] Series and HyperSport drivers Joe Foster and Steve Maxwell won the drivers title in a Mustang GT.

Ford and [[LINK|lang_en|Michelin|Michelin]] teamed up to provide custom-engineered tires for the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Performance|Ford Performance]] vehicle lineup. [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Performance|Ford Performance]] director Dave Pericak said: "That confidence extends from our upcoming racing effort at Le Mans in 2016 with the all-new [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_GT|Ford GT]], to the Ford Performance vehicle lineup, including the [[LINK|lang_en|Shelby_GT350|Shelby GT350]] and F-150 Raptor". [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]

caption.text: A GT racing version of the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Mustang|Ford Mustang]], competing in the [[LINK|lang_en|IMSA_Continental_Tire_Sports_Car_Challenge|Koni Challenge]] in 2005

items.text: Touring cars

Ford has campaigned touring cars such as the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Focus_(international)|Focus]], [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Falcon_(Australia)|Falcon]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Contour|Contour]] / [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Mondeo|Mondeo]] and the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Sierra|Sierra]] [[LINK|lang_en|Cosworth|Cosworth]] in many different series throughout the years. Notably, Mondeo drivers finished 1,2,3 in the 2000 [[LINK|lang_en|British_Touring_Car_Championship|British Touring Car Championship]] and Falcon drivers placed 1,2,3 in the [[LINK|lang_en|2005_V8_Supercar_Championship_Series|2005 V8 Supercar Championship Series]].

caption.text: [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Performance_Racing|Ford Performance Racing]] [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Falcon_(Australia)|Ford Falcon]] [[LINK|lang_en|V8_Supercar|V8 Supercar]] at Eastern Creek in Australia in 2008

items.text: Drag racing

In [[LINK|lang_en|Drag_racing|drag racing]], [[LINK|lang_en|John_Force_Racing|John Force Racing]] drivers [[LINK|lang_en|John_Force|John Force]], [[LINK|lang_en|Tony_Pedregon|Tony Pedregon]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Robert_Hight|Robert Hight]] have piloted [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Mustang|Ford Mustang]] [[LINK|lang_en|Funny_Car|Funny Cars]] to several [[LINK|lang_en|National_Hot_Rod_Association|NHRA]] titles in recent seasons. Teammates [[LINK|lang_en|Tim_Wilkerson|Tim Wilkerson]] and Bob Tasca III also drive Mustangs in Funny Car.
Drifting

Ford has branched out into [[LINK|lang_en|Drifting_(motorsport)|drifting]] with the introduction of the new model Mustang. Most noticeable is the Turquoise and Blue Falken Tires Mustang driven by [[LINK|lang_en|Vaughn_Gittin,_Jr.|Vaughn Gittin, Jr.]], (A.K.A. "JR") that produces 750 RWHP (Rear Wheel Horsepower).
Environmental initiatives
Compressed natural gas

The [[LINK|lang_en|Alternative_fossil_fuel|alternative fossil fuel]] vehicles, such as some versions of the [[LINK|lang_en|Crown_Victoria|Crown Victoria]] especially in fleet and taxi service, operate on [[LINK|lang_en|Compressed_natural_gas|compressed natural gas]] —or CNG. Some CNG vehicles have dual fuel tanks – one for gasoline, the other for CNG – the same engine can operate on either fuel via a selector switch.
Flexible fuel vehicles

[[LINK|lang_en|Flexible_fuel_vehicle|Flexible fuel vehicles]] are designed to operate smoothly using a wide range of available [[LINK|lang_en|Ethanol_fuel|ethanol fuel]] mixtures—from pure gasoline to [[LINK|lang_en|Bioethanol|bioethanol]]-gasoline blends such as [[LINK|lang_en|E85|E85]] (85% [[LINK|lang_en|Ethanol_fuel|ethanol]] and 15% gasoline) or [[LINK|lang_en|Common_ethanol_fuel_mixtures|E100]] (neat [[LINK|lang_en|Hydrous|hydrous]] ethanol) in Brazil. Part of the challenge of successful marketing alternative and flexible fuel vehicles in the U.S. is the general lack of establishment of sufficient [[LINK|lang_en|Fueling_station|fueling stations]], which would be essential for these vehicles to be attractive to a wide range of consumers. Significant efforts to ramp up production and distribution of [[LINK|lang_en|E85|E85]] fuels are underway and expanding. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] Current Ford E100 Flex sold in the Brazilian market are the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Courier|Courier]], [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_EcoSport|Ford EcoSport]], [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Fiesta|Ford Fiesta]], [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Focus_(international)|Ford Focus]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Ka|Ford Ka]].

caption.text: The Ford Focus Flexifuel was the first [[LINK|lang_en|Common_ethanol_fuel_mixtures#E85|E85]] [[LINK|lang_en|Flexible_fuel_vehicle|flexible fuel vehicle]] commercially available in the European market.

items.text: Electric drive vehicles
Hybrid electric vehicles
In 2004, Ford and Toyota agreed a patent sharing accord which granted Ford access to certain hybrid technology patented by Toyota; in exchange, Ford licensed Toyota some of its own patents.

[[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] In 2004, Ford introduced the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Escape_Hybrid|Escape Hybrid]]. With this vehicle, Ford was third to the automotive market with a [[LINK|lang_en|Hybrid_vehicle|hybrid electric vehicle]] and the first hybrid electric [[LINK|lang_en|Sport_utility_vehicle|SUV]] to market. This was also the first hybrid electric vehicle with a [[LINK|lang_en|Flexible_fuel|flexible fuel]] capability to run on [[LINK|lang_en|E85|E85]]. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] The Escape's platform mate [[LINK|lang_en|Mercury_Mariner|Mercury Mariner]] was also available with the hybrid-electric system in the 2006 model year—a full year ahead of schedule. The similar [[LINK|lang_en|Mazda_Tribute|Mazda Tribute]] will also receive a hybrid-electric powertrain option, along with many other vehicles in the Ford vehicle line.

In 2005, Ford announced a goal to make 250,000 hybrids a year by 2010, but by mid-2006 announced that it would not meet that goal, due to excessively high costs and the lack of sufficient supplies of the hybrid-electric batteries and drivetrain system components.

[[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] Instead, Ford has committed to accelerating development of next-generation hybrid-electric power plants in Britain, in collaboration with Volvo.
This engineering study is expected to yield more than 100 new hybrid-electric vehicle models and derivatives.

In September 2007, Ford announced a partnership with [[LINK|lang_en|Southern_California_Edison|Southern California Edison]] (SCE) to examine how [[LINK|lang_en|Plug-in_hybrid|plug-in hybrids]] will work with the electrical grid. Under the multimillion-dollar, multi-year project, Ford will convert a demonstration fleet of [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Escape_Hybrid|Ford Escape Hybrids]] into plug-in hybrids, and SCE will evaluate how the vehicles might interact with the home and the utility's electrical grid. Some of the vehicles will be evaluated "in typical customer settings", according to Ford. [[CITE|128|http://www.eere.energy.gov/news/enn.cfm#id_11093]] [[CITE|161|https://web.archive.org/web/20071011195651/http://media.ford.com/newsroom/release_display.cfm?release=26326]]

On June 12, 2008, [[LINK|lang_en|USDOE|USDOE]] expanded its own fleet of alternative fuel and advanced technology vehicles with the addition of a Ford Escape Plug-In Hybrid Flex-Fuel Vehicle. The vehicle is equipped with a 10-kilowatt (13 hp) [[LINK|lang_en|Lithium-ion|lithium-ion]] battery supplied by [[LINK|lang_en|Johnson_Controls-Saft|Johnson Controls-Saft]] that stores enough electric energy to drive up to 30 miles (48 km) at speeds of up to 40 mph (64 km/h). [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] In March 2009, Ford launched hybrid versions of the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Fusion_Hybrid|Ford Fusion Hybrid]] and the [[LINK|lang_en|Mercury_Milan_Hybrid|Mercury Milan Hybrid]] in the United States, both as 2010 models. [[CITE|266|]]

As of November 2014, Ford has produced for retail sales the following hybrid electric vehicles: [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Escape_Hybrid|Ford Escape Hybrid]] (2004–2012), [[LINK|lang_en|Mercury_Mariner#Hybrid|Mercury Mariner Hybrid]] (2005–2010), [[LINK|lang_en|Mercury_Milan_Hybrid|Mercury Milan Hybrid]] (2009–2010), [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Fusion_Hybrid|Ford Fusion Hybrid]] (2009–present), [[LINK|lang_en|Lincoln_MKZ_Hybrid|Lincoln MKZ Hybrid]] (2010–present), [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_C-Max_Hybrid|Ford C-Max Hybrid]] (2012–present), and [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Mondeo_Hybrid|Ford Mondeo Hybrid]] (2014–present). By June 2012, Ford had sold 200,000 full hybrids in the US since 2004, [[CITE|15|http://businessgreen.com/bg/news/2186508/ford-tips-hybrids-overshadow-electric-cars]] and, as of September 2014, the carmaker has sold over 344 thousand hybrids in the United States. [[CITE|15|http://businessgreen.com/bg/news/2186508/ford-tips-hybrids-overshadow-electric-cars]] [[CITE|33|http://hybridcars.com/december-2012-dashboard]] [[CITE|67|http://hybridcars.com/december-2013-dashboard]] [[CITE|114|http://hybridcars.com/september-2014-dashboard]] The top selling hybrids in the U.S. market are the Fusion Hybrid with 127,572 units, followed by Escape Hybrid with 117,997 units, and the C-Max Hybrid with 54,236. [[CITE|33|http://hybridcars.com/december-2012-dashboard]] [[CITE|67|http://hybridcars.com/december-2013-dashboard]] [[CITE|114|http://hybridcars.com/september-2014-dashboard]] [[CITE|165|http://hybridcars.com/news/december-2011-dashboard-sales-still-climbing-35093.html]] [[CITE|178|http://www.afdc.energy.gov/afdc/data/vehicles.html]] As of November 2014, Ford is the world's second largest manufacturer of hybrids after [[LINK|lang_en|Toyota_Motor_Corporation|Toyota Motor Corporation]], with 400,000 hybrid electric vehicles produced since their introduction in 2004. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]

caption.text: [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Escape|Ford Escape]] [[LINK|lang_en|Plug-in_hybrid|plug-in hybrid]] test vehicle

Mulally (second from left) with then-President [[LINK|lang_en|George_W._Bush|George W. Bush]] at the [[LINK|lang_en|Kansas_City_Assembly|Kansas City Assembly]] plant in [[LINK|lang_en|Claycomo,_Missouri|Claycomo]], Missouri on March 20, 2007, [[LINK|lang_en|https:|touting]] Ford's new hybrid cars

items.text: Plug-in electric vehicles

As of October 2014, Ford has produced the following [[LINK|lang_en|Plug-in_electric_vehicle|plug-in electric vehicles]] : the all-electric [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Ranger_EV|Ford Ranger EV]] (1997–2002), [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_TH!NK|Ford TH!NK]] (1999–2003), [[LINK|lang_en|Azure_Transit_Connect_Electric|Transit Connect]] (2010–2012), and [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Focus_Electric|Ford Focus Electric]] (December 2011–present); and the [[LINK|lang_en|Plug-in_hybrid|plug-in hybrids]] [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_C-Max_Energi|C-MAX Energi]] (October 2012–present) and the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Fusion_Energi|Fusion Energi]] (February 2013–present), sold under the Mondeo nameplate in Europe. [[CITE|205|http://autoblog.com/2009/03/05/ford-ceo-mullaly-expects-major-portion-of-fords-will-be-electr]] [[CITE|233|http://apps1.eere.energy.gov/news/news_detail.cfm/news_id=12178]] Since the launch of the Focus Electric in 2011, combined sales of all Ford [[LINK|lang_en|Plug-in_electric_vehicle|plug-in electric models]] amounted to just over 56,000 through October 2015. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]

Bill Ford was one of the first top industry executives to make regular use of a [[LINK|lang_en|Battery_electric_vehicle|battery electric vehicle]], a [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Ranger_EV|Ford Ranger EV]], while the company contracted with the [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Postal_Service|United States Postal Service]] to deliver electric postal vans based on the Ranger EV platform. Ford discontinued a line of electric [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Ranger|Ranger]] [[LINK|lang_en|Pickup_truck|pickup trucks]] and ordered them destroyed, though it reversed in January 2005, after environmentalist protest. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] The all-electric pickup truck leased 205 units to individuals and 1,500 units to fleets in the U.S. from 1998 to 2002. [[CITE|34|https://rand.org/pubs/monograph_reports/2007/MR1578.pdf]]

From 2009 to 2011, Ford offered the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_TH!NK|Ford TH!NK]] car. Ford ended production and ordered all the cars repossessed and destroyed, even as many of the people leasing them begged to be able to buy the cars from Ford. After outcry from the lessees and activists in the US and Norway, Ford returned the cars to Norway for sale. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] 440 units were leased in the U.S. from 1999 until 2003.

In 2017, CEO of Ford [[LINK|lang_en|Mark_Fields_(businessman)|Mark Fields]] announced that the company will invest $4.5 billion in further development of plug-in electric vehicles by 2020. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]

The [[LINK|lang_en|Azure_Transit_Connect_Electric|Azure Transit Connect Electric]] was an [[LINK|lang_en|Electric_vehicle|all-electric]] [[LINK|lang_en|Van|van]] developed as a collaboration between [[LINK|lang_en|Azure_Dynamics|Azure Dynamics]] and Ford Motor Company, but Azure was the official manufacturer of record. [[CITE|109|https://blogs.wsj.com/drivers-seat/2010/09/24/ford-switches-role-with-new-electric-van]] The Transit Connect Electric had an official [[LINK|lang_en|US_Environmental_Protection_Agency|US Environmental Protection Agency]] all-electric range of 56 mi (90 km). [[CITE|123|http://fueleconomy.gov/feg/Find.do?action=sbs&id=31893]] The EPA rated the combined city/highway [[LINK|lang_en|Fuel_economy_in_automobiles|fuel economy]] at 62 [[LINK|lang_en|Miles_per_gallon_gasoline_equivalent|miles per gallon gasoline equivalent]] (3.8 L/100 km equivalent). [[CITE|123|http://fueleconomy.gov/feg/Find.do?action=sbs&id=31893]] Deliveries for fleet customers in the U.S. and Canada began in December 2010. [[CITE|154|https://nytimes.com/2010/12/08/business/08electric.html]] Production of the electric van was stopped in March 2012 as a result of Azure's bankruptcy protection filing. Ford continues to provide servicing. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] Around 500 units were sold before Azure stopped production. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]

The [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Focus_Electric|Ford Focus Electric]] is based on the next generation [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Focus_(North_America)|Focus]] internal combustion vehicle, converted to an [[LINK|lang_en|Battery_electric_vehicle|all-electric]] propulsion system as a production [[LINK|lang_en|Electric_car|electric car]] by Magna International, and retail sales began in the U.S. in December 2011. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] The Focus Electric has an EPA rated range of 76 mi (122 km) and a combined city/highway fuel economy of 105 [[LINK|lang_en|Miles_per_gallon_gasoline_equivalent|miles per gallon gasoline equivalent]] (2.2 L/100 km). [[CITE|257|http://fueleconomy.gov/feg/Find.do?action=sbs&id=32278&id=33024&id=34130]] Available also in Canada and several European countries, 3,965 units have been sold in the U.S. through September 2014. [[CITE|33|http://hybridcars.com/december-2012-dashboard]] [[CITE|67|http://hybridcars.com/december-2013-dashboard]] [[CITE|114|http://hybridcars.com/september-2014-dashboard]] [[CITE|6|http://greencarcongress.com/2012/08/volt-20120803.html]]

The [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_C-Max_Energi|Ford C-Max Energi]] is a [[LINK|lang_en|Plug-in_hybrid|plug-in hybrid]] released in the U.S. in October 2012. The C-Max Energi has an EPA rated [[LINK|lang_en|All-electric_range|all-electric range]] of 20 mi (32 km) and a combined city/highway fuel economy in [[LINK|lang_en|All-electric_mode|all-electric mode]] at 88 [[LINK|lang_en|Miles_per_gallon_of_gasoline_equivalent|MPG-e]] (2.7 L/100 km). [[CITE|22|http://fueleconomy.gov/feg/Find.do?action=sbs&id=34662&id=34089&id=33398&id=33336#tab1]] U.S. sales totaled 33,509 unitsthrough December 2016. [[CITE|33|http://hybridcars.com/december-2012-dashboard]] [[CITE|67|http://hybridcars.com/december-2013-dashboard]] [[CITE|47|http://hybridcars.com/december-2014-dashboard]] [[CITE|73|http://hybridcars.com/december-2015-dashboard]] [[CITE|111|http://hybridcars.com/december-2016-dashboard]] Deliveries of the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Fusion_Energi|Ford Fusion Energi]] began in the United States in February 2013. [[CITE|172|http://pricinginsider.carsdirect.com/2013/02/27/2013-ford-fusion-energi-fuel-economy-pricing-and-release-date]] [[CITE|206|https://insideevs.com/february-2013-plug-in-electric-vehicle-sales-report-card]] The Fusion Energi has an all-electric range of 20 mi (32 km) and an equivalent fuel economy EPA rating of 88 MPG-e (2.7 L/100 km). [[CITE|22|http://fueleconomy.gov/feg/Find.do?action=sbs&id=34662&id=34089&id=33398&id=33336#tab1]] As of December 2016, a total of 43,327 units have been delivered in the U.S. since its inception. [[CITE|67|http://hybridcars.com/december-2013-dashboard]] [[CITE|47|http://hybridcars.com/december-2014-dashboard]] [[CITE|73|http://hybridcars.com/december-2015-dashboard]] [[CITE|111|http://hybridcars.com/december-2016-dashboard]]

Both Energi models share the same powertrain technology and have the same EPA combined city/highway fuel economy in [[LINK|lang_en|Charge-sustaining|hybrid]] operation of 38 mpg ‑US (6.2 L/100 km; 46 mpg ‑imp ). [[CITE|22|http://fueleconomy.gov/feg/Find.do?action=sbs&id=34662&id=34089&id=33398&id=33336#tab1]] When asked about a battery-electric vehicle with a 200-mile (320 km) range, Fields said in April 2016 "Clearly that's something we're developing for". Ford has a pending trademark application on the "Model E" name, [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] preventing the [[LINK|lang_en|Tesla_Model_3|Tesla Model 3]] in using the name. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]

In October 2017, Ford announced its Team Edison battery-electric vehicle group to lead the company's renewed efforts into the EV market, in which it currently offers only the Focus subcompact and has plans for a small 300-mile SUV by 2020.
[[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] The new team will be headquartered in Detroit and have offices in Europe and Asia.
[[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]

caption.text: The [[LINK|lang_en|Azure_Transit_Connect_Electric|Azure Transit Connect Electric]] was produced between 2010 and 2012 as a collaboration between [[LINK|lang_en|Azure_Dynamics|Azure Dynamics]] and Ford Motor Company.
The [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Fusion_Energi|Ford Fusion Energi]] [[LINK|lang_en|Plug-in_hybrid|plug-in hybrid]] shares its powertrain with the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_C-Max_Energi|Ford C-Max Energi]].

items.text: Hydrogen

Ford also continues to study [[LINK|lang_en|Fuel_cell|fuel cell]]-powered electric powertrains and has demonstrated hydrogen-fueled [[LINK|lang_en|Internal_combustion_engine|internal combustion engine]] technologies, as well as developing the next-generation hybrid-electric systems. Compared with conventional vehicles, [[LINK|lang_en|Hybrid_vehicle|hybrid vehicles]] and/or fuel cell vehicles decrease air pollution emissions as well as sound levels, with favorable impacts upon respiratory health and decrease of [[LINK|lang_en|Noise_health_effects|noise health effects]].

Ford has launched the production of [[LINK|lang_en|Hydrogen_vehicle|hydrogen-powered]] shuttle buses, using hydrogen instead of gasoline in a standard [[LINK|lang_en|Hydrogen_vehicle#Hydrogen_internal_combustion|internal combustion engine]], for use at airports and convention centers. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] At the 2006 [[LINK|lang_en|Greater_Los_Angeles_Auto_Show|Greater Los Angeles Auto Show]], Ford showcased a hydrogen fuel cell version of its Explorer SUV. The Fuel cell Explorer has a combined output of 174 hp (130 kW). It has a large hydrogen storage tank which is situated in the center of the car taking the original place of the conventional model's automatic transmission. The centered position of the tank assists the vehicle reach a notable range of 350 miles (563 km), the farthest for a fuel cell vehicle so far. The fuel cell Explorer the first in a series of prototypes partly funded by the [[LINK|lang_en|United_States_Department_of_Energy|United States Department of Energy]] to expand efforts to determine the feasibility of hydrogen- powered vehicles. The fuel cell Explorer is one of several vehicles with green technology being featured at the L.A. show, including the 2008 Ford Escape Hybrid, PZEV emissions compliant Fusion and Focus models and a 2008 Ford F-Series Super Duty outfitted with Ford's clean diesel technology.
Increased fuel efficiency

Ford Motor Company announced it will accelerate its plans to produce more fuel-efficient cars, changing both its North American manufacturing plans and its lineup of vehicles available in the United States.

In terms of North American manufacturing, the company will convert three existing truck and sport utility vehicle (SUV) plants for small car production, with the first conversion at its Michigan Truck Plant.
In addition, Ford's assembly plants near Mexico City, Mexico, and in Louisville, Kentucky, will convert from pickups and SUVs to small cars, including the Ford Fiesta, by 2011.
Ford will also introduce to North America six of its European small vehicles, including two versions of the Ford Fiesta, by the end of 2012.

Ford of Europe developed the [[LINK|lang_en|ECOnetic|ECOnetic]] programme to address the market and legislative need for higher fuel efficiency and lower CO2 emissions. As opposed to the [[LINK|lang_en|Hybrid_engine|hybrid engine]] technology used in competitor products such as the [[LINK|lang_en|Toyota_Prius|Toyota Prius]], ECOnetic improves existing technology. Using lower consuming [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Duratorq_engine|Duratorq TDCi]] diesel engines, and based on a combination of improved aerodynamics, lower resistance, and improved efficiency, the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Fiesta|Ford Fiesta]] is currently the lowest emitting mass-produced car in Europe [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] while the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Focus_(international)|2012 Ford Focus ECOnetic]] will have better fuel consumption than the Prius or the [[LINK|lang_en|Volkswagen_Golf|Volkswagen Golf]] [[LINK|lang_en|BlueMotion|BlueMotion]]. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] ECOnetic is not presently planned to be sold in North American due to current perceived lower consumer demand. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]
Ford has challenged University teams to create a vehicle that is simple, durable, lightweight, and come equipped with a base target price of only $7,000.

The students from [[LINK|lang_en|Aachen_University|Aachen University]] created the "2015 Ford Model T". [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]

In 2000, under the leadership of the current Ford chairman, William Clay Ford, the company announced [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] a planned 25 percent improvement in the average mileage of its light truck fleet – including its popular [[LINK|lang_en|Sport_utility_vehicle|SUVs]] – to be completed by the 2005 [[LINK|lang_en|Calendar_year|calendar year]]. In 2003, Ford announced that competitive market conditions and technological and cost challenges would prevent the company from achieving this goal. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]

For the 2007 model year, Ford had thirteen U.S. models that achieve 30 miles per gallon or better (based on the highway fuel economy estimates of the EPA) and several of Ford's vehicles were recognized in the EPA and Department of Energy Fuel Economy Guide for best-in-class fuel economy.
Ford claimed to have eliminated nearly three million pounds of smog-forming emissions from their U.S. cars and light trucks over the 2004 to 2006 model years.

[[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]] However, the United States Environmental Protection Agency has linked Ford to 54 [[LINK|lang_en|Superfund|Superfund]] toxic waste sites, twelve of which have been cleaned up and deleted from the list. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]
PC power management

On March 2010, Ford announced its [[LINK|lang_en|PC_power_management|PC power management]] system which it developed with NightWatchman software from [[LINK|lang_en|1E|1E]]. The company is expected to save $1.2m on power cost and reduce carbon footprint by an estimated 16,000 to 25,000 metric tons annually when the system is fully implemented.
According to company, reduction in carbon footprint and power cost will be achieved by developing 'Power Profiles' for every PC in the company.
[[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]
Sponsorships

Ford sponsors numerous events and sports facilities around the US, most notably the [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Center_(Evansville)|Ford Center]] in downtown [[LINK|lang_en|Evansville,_Indiana|Evansville, Indiana]], and [[LINK|lang_en|Ford_Field|Ford Field]] in [[LINK|lang_en|Downtown_Detroit|downtown Detroit]]. [[CITE|7|http://nps.gov/nhl/find/statelists/mi/FordPiquette.pdf]]

Ford has also been a major sponsor of the [[LINK|lang_en|UEFA_Champions_League|UEFA Champions League]] for over two decades and is also a longtime sponsor of the [[LINK|lang_en|Sky_plc|Sky media channel's]] coverage of [[LINK|lang_en|Premier_League|Premier League]] football. Senior Ford marketer Mark Jones explained in May 2013 the process behind the two sponsorship deals:
We start with a blank piece of paper and work out if the sponsorship still works for us and ask does it meet our objectives?
We want to find a moment in time when people come together and have a collective experience and we achieve this through the sponsorships.
